Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
After a disaster, such as an earthquake, inspectors are tasked with assessing the integrity of affected buildings and structures. Depending on the scale of the disaster, the number of required inspections can range into the thousands. There are both public safety and economic pressures to consider, and so rapid and accurate assessments of buildings and structures are vital. The goal of this research project is to develop a method using digital image analysis and artificial intelligence to assess the integrity of civil structures after a natural disaster. Fully realized, this technology will enable post-disaster inspectors to rapidly and accurately estimate structural damage using only a digital camera and portable computer.

Research in a comprehensive method of computer vision-based structural assessment will be pursued, one that is flexible enough to operate in highly varied and challenging field environments. To be truly comprehensive, such a methodology must be hierarchical, first recognizing the system-level context of structural components observed in an image and then leveraging that information to augment localized descriptions of damage extracted from segmentation routines. In this research program, the visual and instrumentation records of NEES experiments, available through the NEESHub, will be mined and analyzed to validate the algorithm. The research program will advance understanding as to how visually observable damage correlates to structural performance, and will provide insights into the suitability of hierarchical learning techniques for use in the field of computer vision-based structural assessment. More broadly, the project will result in an extensible method of visual, non-contact structural assessment that will provide a foundation for future structural monitoring system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored how images and videos can be used for damage detection and structural assessment of civil infrastructure systems, with a particular emphasis on forensic analysis after a natural disaster. Over the four year research program a variety of focused studies were performed, and a combination of computer vision and artificial intelligence methods were developed and tested as a result.


With respect to intellectual merit, major accomplishments include:

-A process for generating 3D point cloud images of infrastructure that offers a several orders of magnitude improvement in resolution over existing methods.
-A suite of data analytics techniques for analyzing and quantifying damage in high resolution 3D point clouds. 
-A new algorithmic process for repurposing video recordings of earthquake events for post-disaster triage assessments.
-The creation of a fundamental process for reducing the impact of outliers in statistical analytics, particularly those related to 3D computational geometry.
-8 journal publications, 1 patent filing, and 9 conference publications


With respect to broader impacts, major accomplishments include:

-Improvements in infrastructure and community resilience through better post-disaster and life-cycle assessments
-Interdisciplinary research training for three PhD students, three masters students, three undergraduate students, and a post-doctoral scholar. One PhD student also received extensive training in research translation and entrepreneurship as a result of this award.
-An ongoing research commercialization and translation effort, supported by an associated NSF I-Corps award, related to the developed point cloud generation and analytical techniques. 
-New course offerings and teaching modules that expose students to the interdisciplinary fields of computer vision and data analytics as they relate to civil infrastructure systems.
-Training to professionals through ASCE webinars, as well as in-person training for professionals in the intelligence and national security domains.

Modified by: David Lattanzi
